Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gnarlnib’s Nibbling

’Twas flemper, and the slorpy ducts
Did grickle in the sump;
All mimsy were the constructs,
And the ink-raths in a clump.

“Beware the Gnarlnib, son of mine!
The jaw that chokes, the tooth that grips!
It warps the feed, it glumps the line,
And scrimps with inky, viscid lips!”

He took his flink-flame staff in hand,
Long time the glogging foe he sought—
So rested he by the chann-gland,
And stood a while in glumpish thought.

And, as in glumpish thought he stood,
The Gnarlnib, with its eyes of clot,
Came skritching from the Fount-wood,
Burbulating, thick with grot.

One, two! And through and through
The flink-flame’s tongue did lick and fast;
It seared the warp, the flow ran true,
Its glogging, grickling days were past.

“And hast thou set the ebon-feed?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Hurroo! Hurreed!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas flemper, and the slorpy ducts
Did grickle in the sump;
All mimsy were the constructs,
And the ink-raths in a clump.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "hollow grind on an O1 blade". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Grindsleuth's Glave

’Twas coaldamp, and the clinkering forge-grols
Did grintle and scrawm in the cinder-heap;
All scorious were the slaggy knolls,
And the dross-wights outcreep.

“Beware the Grummlescale, my son!
The jaws that blunt, the hide of scale!
Beware the Pitting-Pox, and shun
The morgerous oxid-trail!”

He took his O-one glave in hand,
Its edge a scrything, moon-thin gleam;
He sought it through the cinder-land,
And by the quenchious stream.

And, as in quenchious thought he stood,
The Grummlescale, with eyes of blight,
Came rumbling through the soot-stained wood,
And breathed a scaling night.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The O-one blade went whicker-snik!
It cleft the drossy hide in two,
And stained the metal quick.

“And hast thou felled the Grummlescale?
Return, my blade-bright boy, to me!
O triumph-hiss! O ringing-scale!”
He whistled in his glee.

’Twas coaldamp, and the clinkering forge-grols
Did grintle and scrawm in the cinder-heap;
All scorious were the slaggy knolls,
And the dross-wights outcreep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "forged leaf scroll". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Vellumgloom

’Twas umbrish, and the windles high
Did thrumble in the glumphy wood;
Upon a scroll, a scriven-lie,
The Vellumgloom’s dark charm there stood.

“Beware the Vellumgloom, my child!
The jaws that rust, the leaves that bind!
Beware the script, so false and wild,
And shun the groaning glade behind.”

He took his brightsome brand in hand,
He sought the foe of forged design;
Then rested by a Grumble-stand,
And parsed a thought of grummest line.

And as in grummest thought he stayed,
The Vellumgloom, with eyes of blight,
Came whickering through the snarléd glade,
And clankered in the fading light.

Thwick-thwack! Thwick-thwack! And through and through
The brightsome blade cut sharp and thin;
It smote the scroll’s foul forgery true,
And let the truthful daylight in.

“And hast thou crushed the scriven-lie?
Come to my arms, my radiant one!
O gladsome day! Hurrah! For-fye!”
He chortled in his joyous run.

’Twas umbrish, and the windles high
Did thrumble in the glumphy wood;
Upon a scroll, a scriven-lie,
The Vellumgloom’s dark charm there stood.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glostfire Glaive

’Twas clay-dark, and the spallish flues
Did shrinker in the kilnwood gloam;
All dunting were the underglues,
And the kiln-wraiths did moam.

“Beware the Crazeglume, my child!
The glaze that crawls, the cracks that clutch!
Shun the scritching sherd-wrack, wild,
And the dunting-touch!”

He took his glostfire glaive in hand:
Long time the vitrine foe he sought—
So rested by the muffle-stand,
And stood in vetrous thought.

And, as in fluxive thought he stood,
The Crazeglume, with eyes of heat,
Came through the pyre-bright kilnwood,
On sinter-staring feet!

One-two! one-two! he watched it lean,
The cone that stooped, a slumpish sight!
He snibbed the bung, he quelled the scene,
And quenched its baleful light.

“And hast thou quelled the Crazeglume?
Come to my arms, my kilnsome boy!
O clinksome day! Huroo! Hurray!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas clay-dark, and the spallish flues
Did shrinker in the kilnwood gloam;
All dunting were the underglues,
And the kiln-wraiths did moam.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "lead type in a composing stick". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Composing-Wick

’Twas platen-press, and the slug-slime type
Did clattergrump in the job-case deep;
All flongish were the ligatures,
And the kern-claws from their sleep.

“Beware the Typogriff, my son!
The jaws that jumble, glyphs askew!
Beware the Quad-beast, and please shun
The galleys’ grumly view!”

He took his bodkin-bright in hand,
His quoin-blade measured for the fight;
He sought the sorts by the Caslon stand,
And set his gauge by morning-light.

And as in fontish thought he stood,
The Typogriff, with eyes of lead,
Came chittering through the pie-strewn wood,
And founts of mackle drooled and spread.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The quoin-blade went, with chink-chunk fast!
He left it locked, a column true,
And proofed the block, from first to last.

“And hast thou set the Typogriff?
Come to my press, my page-bright boy!
O printsome day! A perfect glyph!”
He cried aloud for joy.

’Twas platen-press, and the slug-slime type
Did clattergrump in the job-case deep;
All flongish were the ligatures,
And the kern-claws from their sleep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "urushi lacquer cure". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Lacquermaul

’Twas humident, and the claggy dews
Did skirl and glisten on the rack;
All mirky were the vapour-flues,
And the glumpish Saptraps clack.

“Beware the Lacquermaul, my son!
The jaws that bind, the gloss that sears!
Beware the Fumiclaw, and shun
The tackisome and grumous smears.”

He took his vaporean glaive in hand;
Long time the glazéd foe he sought—
So rested he by the moinous strand,
And stood awhile in tempic thought.

And as in tempic thought he stood,
The Lacquermaul, with eyes of nacre,
Came polymering through the steamy wood,
A-wobbling with a sticky slaker.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The vaporean glaive went snicker-set!
It left the beast, no longer new,
But hardened in a glazen fret.

“And hast thou set the Lacquermaul?
Come to my arms, my lustrous boy!
O glostrous day! Exult! Hooray!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas humident, and the claggy dews
Did skirl and glisten on the rack;
All mirky were the vapour-flues,
And the glumpish Saptraps clack.

poem:
The Plorbian’s Plight

’Twas glummish, and the sludging strows
Did gribble in the sump;
All mirky were the plum-brown flows,
And blueing had begun.

“Beware the Plorbian, child, beware!
The jaws that glorp, the claws that gride!
Its clabbering touch, a soul’s despair,
Where sullied waters slide.”

He took his scour-stick, keen and long,
And sought the boggy shade;
He hummed a low and doughty song,
And was not much afraid.

And as in umbrish thought he stayed,
The Plorbian, with its eyes of blight,
Came sludging from the glummy glade,
A-burbling in the light.

One whisk, one scour! The stick sank deep!
The plum-brown hide began to shrink!
It gave a final, gurgling *gleek*!
And blued beneath the brink.

’Twas glummish, and the sludging strows
Did gribble in the sump;
All mirky were the plum-brown flows,
And blueing had begun.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "farewell at a platform". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Parting at Plyke

’Twas gloomer-lit, and dreggled plykes
Did whimper on the soot-slick stone,
All squelchious were the gantry-spikes,
And the steam-whist moaned a long, low groan.

“Beware the Grimgrime, lad!” he cried,
“Its chuffering breath, its grip of steel!
The track it rides where hopes have died,
The sorrow that its pistons wheel!”

He took his clock-work heart in hand;
Long time the glumpish foe he sought—
Then stilled himself upon the stand,
And locked his grief in platchwork thought.

And as he stood, the great machine,
The Grimgrime, with its eye of brass,
Came clatter-clanging to the scene,
And panted clouds of hissing gas.

One, two! One, two! A final touch,
A hand let go, a closing door.
It pulled away with groaning lurch;
The glumping beast was seen no more.

And has the Grimgrime passed thee by?
The platform cleared, the track lay bare.
He stood beneath a gawping sky,
And breathed the cold and vacant air.

’Twas gloomer-lit, and dreggled plykes
Did whimper on the soot-slick stone,
All squelchious were the gantry-spikes,
And the steam-whist moaned a long, low groan.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "ink brayer and chase". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Fimblegraft

’Twas inklate, and the oily sump
Did with the gribbles teem;
All churking was the press-form’s flumph
Within the gaslight’s gleam.

“Beware the Fimblegraft, my son!
The stridulous squeal, the gracklish bite!
Beware its brayer-path, and shun
Its chundering chase of night!”

He took his platen-wrench in hand,
Long time the clatterous foe he sought.
He rested by the galley-stand
And stood, in iron thought.

And as he mused beside the press,
The Fimblegraft, with gears of dread,
Came clatter-clinking through the mess,
A-whirling o’er the lead!

Heft-ho! Heft-ho! He swung the chase,
A frame of solid, stark!
He shattered its revolving face
And quenched its oily spark.

“And have you stopped its gracklish hum?
My son, you’ve won the day!
O glorious time! Let drumming come!”
He cried in proud display.

’Twas inklate, and the oily sump
Did with the gribbles teem;
No longer did the press-form flumph
Within the gaslight’s gleam.

poem:
The Gyre-Gale’s Cry

’Twas brumous, and the crag-scarps high
Did scumble in the glumish air;
All skirl-sharp were the winds that cry,
And the rime-wraiths out there.

“Beware the Gyre-Gale, my son!
The breath that bites, the claws that skreel!
Shun where its chitter-claws have run,
And its wuthering appeal.”

He took his grappler-axe in hand,
Long time the fridged peak he sought;
To place the flag on that high land
Was his most gleemful thought.

He rested by a summit-stone,
When, from a cleft of icy flue,
The Gyre-Gale, with a grister-moan,
Came burling, cold and blue.

With axe-head sharp and handle true,
He clove the gale in twain;
He thrunched it once, he thrunched it through,
And stilled its windy pain.

“And hast thou quelled the Gyre-Gale?
Come to my arms, my sun-bright boy!
The peak now wears its silken veil,
O thrilljoy! Gladsome joy!”

’Twas brumous, and the crag-scarps high
Did scumble in the glumish air;
All skirl-sharp were the winds that cry,
And the rime-wraiths out there.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "luthier's soundpost setter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Fiddlespawn

’Twas gloaming, and the f-hole dark
Did fret the luthier, lone and grim.
“Beware the Fiddlespawn, and hark
The wolf-note whimpering from the rim!”

He took his grittle-staff in hand;
Long time the sound-slain foe he sought.
He passed the purfling’s pinstripe band,
Then stood awhile in fretful thought.

And as in rib-bound gloom he crept,
The Fiddlespawn, with soul of spruce,
Stood canted, and the cello wept,
And flensed all music from its use.

A nudge, a twist! The staff so keen
Went zicker-zack and found its place;
He set the soul, a sight unseen,
And wiped the scrawl from off its face.

“And hast thou set the Fiddlespawn?
Draw bow to string, my gleesome boy!”
Oh plangent day! Cadenza! Fawn!
He trills now in his resonant joy.

’Twas gloaming, and the f-hole dark
Did fret the luthier, lone and grim.
“Beware the Fiddlespawn, and hark
The wolf-note whimpering from the rim!”

poem:
The Nychthimeron

’Twas gloam-time, and the thorn-slat vines
Did frill within the shade;
All stilling were the petaline,
And the moon-moths unafraid.

“Beware the Somnascent, my dear,
The buds with vex-scented sighs!
The Calyx-claws that cricke so near,
The bloom that glamours sleepy eyes!”

He held his gleam-knife in his hand,
And by the selen-wood he stayed,
And waited in that fragrabient land,
For spiky stems that stirred and swayed.

And as in glimmer-ghast he watched,
The Somnascent, with waxen flame,
Began to creeple, pale and splotched,
A hush-hiss siffling as it came!

One cut! Two cuts! And through and through
The gleam-knife’s edge did sheer and shear!
He took its lucent head, and drew
Away from all its glamour clear.

“And have you brought the Somnascent?
Come to my arms, my constant one!
O brilliant, brief, magnificent!
Oh, see the task so deftly done!”

’Twas gloam-time, and the thorn-slat vines
Did frill within the shade;
All stilling were the petaline,
And the moon-moths unafraid.

poem:
Patchwerk

’Twas krelling, and the drone-dank nodes
Did vobble in the rack;
All glumptious were the over-loads,
And the filtrous feedback.

“Beware the Patchwerk, son, my own!
The jacks that bite, the cords that snatch!
Beware the LFO, and shun
The drone of the Sequentch!”

He took his VCA-clamp in hand,
His gating-jack held taut;
He sought the foe across that land
Of volt-deep, tangled thought.

And as in knob-twiced thought he stood,
The Patchwerk, with its LED,
Came whumphering through the wire-wood,
And gnarfling, filled with dread.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The VCA-clamp went knicker-knack!
He plunged it in the port marked “Thru”,
And un-squelched its squonking track.

“And hast thou tamed the tangled dread?
Come to my arms, my clever boy!
O voltious boom! Control is had!”
He pulsed with sonic joy.

’Twas krelling, and the drone-dank nodes
Did vobble in the rack;
All glumptious were the over-loads,
And the filtrous feedback.

poem:
The Spooligarde

’Twas warbly, and the ferric fens
Did skritch and slurve within the glade;
All hissome were the audio-dens,
And the mono-paths unmade.

“Beware the Spooligarde, my son!
The jaws that drone, the claws that fray!
Beware the Play-head bird, and shun
The cronking Capstan in its way!”

He took his D-magnet blade in hand;
Long time the flutter-foe he sought—
So rested he by the Bias-tree,
And stood a while in thought.

And, as in dolby-dim he stood,
The Spooligarde, with eyes of fire,
Came clinkering through the whicker-wood,
And grumbled sounds of sonic dire!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The D-magnet blade went whicker-whump!
It fell, its signal skewed askew,
And he left its silent, mangled clump.

“And hast thou slain the Spooligarde?
Come to my arms, my steady boy!
O playback day! Pure-toned, unmarred!”
He chuffed in his audial joy.

’Twas warbly, and the ferric fens
Did skritch and slurve within the glade;
All hissome were the audio-dens,
And the mono-paths unmade.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "opal play‑of‑color flash". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glommergloom's Gleam

'Twas glimming, and the gliff-stones cold
Did umbrate in the haze;
The Glommergloom, a sight to hold,
Set all the air ablaze.

"Beware the Glommergloom, my son!
The flash that fuddles thought,
The chromatrap it spins is one
By which the dazed are caught."

He took his mirrorglass blade in hand,
And by the gnarble-oak,
He searched that scintillant, grim land,
But not a word he spoke.

He rested by a craggen peak,
His mirrorglass held low,
Then heard a chittering, sharp skreak
From out the gloom below.

A flash! A blaze of opal-play!
The air began to thrum;
The mirrorglass blade went clash-a-klay,
And struck the monster numb.

"And is the Glommergloom undone?
Come in, O triumph-child!
My praise for this great deed is won,"
The joyful father smiled.

'Twas glimming, and the gliff-stones cold
Did umbrate in the haze;
The Glommergloom, a sight to hold,
Set all the air ablaze.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glimmergrope

’Twas glumphing, and the pionic swarms
Did chitter-skritch upon the dew;
All frumpled were the peony forms,
And the Glimmergrope was new.

“Beware the Glimmergrope, my son!
The jaws that bite, the glissing dread!
Beware the scuttlestream, and shun
The mandibrute and its vile head!”

He took his trowel-blade in hand,
Long time the monstrous foe he sought—
He strode out through that pearly land
And rested by a bud, in thought.

And as he stood beside the bloom,
The Glimmergrope, with eyes of bead,
Came thrumbling through the dawning gloom,
Intent upon its nectar-greed.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The trowel-blade went whicker-whack!
It cloved the beastly thing in two,
And snapped its chittering thorax-track.

“And hast thou slain the Glimmergrope?
Come to my arms, my gleamy boy!
O gleesome day! O final hope!”
He chortle-chucked in his great joy.

’Twas glumphing, and the pionic swarms
Did chitter-skritch upon the dew;
All frumpled were the peony forms,
And the Glimmergrope was new.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Lyssajew

’Twas grunion, and the gryllic probes
Did frict and zizzer in the grid;
All flimsy were the sine-wave lobes,
And the voltmaws were hid.

“Beware the Lyssajew, my son!
The phase that twists, the skewing bright!
Beware the Vectrex-bird, and shun
The glarish, blooming cathode-light!”

He took his transient probe in hand,
His ohmic shield held fast and true;
He sought his foe by the CRT-stand,
And scanned the quantic view.

And as in focused thought he stood,
The Lyssajew, with eyes of beam,
Came gimbling greenly through the wood
Of wire, with a hum-whirr scream!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The transient probe went krackt and snick!
It fell, its form now split askew,
He left it, tuned and dead-quick.

“And hast thou tamed the Lyssajew?
Come to my arms, my resonant boy!
O glimmervast day! Calibrate! Calloo!”
He chirped within his joy.

’Twas grunion, and the gryllic probes
Did frict and zizzer in the grid;
All stable were the sine-wave lobes,
And the voltmaws now grid.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Scentagruel

’Twas musky, and the glabrous groves
Did gyre and burble on the skin;
All urksome were the civet-droves,
And the fumid notes within.

“Beware the Scentagruel, my son!
The pounce-fanged jaws, the chitter-reek!
Beware its cloud, and swiftly run
From that sweet-stink upon the cheek!”

He took his flacon-blade in hand,
Long time the waftering foe he sought—
Then rested by a pulse-point stand,
And stood a while in calmish thought.

And as in thoughtful wait he stood,
The Scentagruel, with eyes of nacre,
Came snuffling from his being’s wood,
And whiffled, growing ever acrid.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The flacon-blade went dabber-dight!
He bore the blast, then breathed it new,
And waited for the scent’s long night.

“And hast thou tamed the Scentagruel?
Come to my arms, my fragrant boy!
O floric day! A musken spell!”
He chortled in his velveteen joy.

’Twas musky, and the glabrous groves
Did gyre and burble on the skin;
All urksome were the civet-droves,
And the fumid notes within.

poem:
The Platen-Press

’Twas inky-dark, the leaden slugs
Did scryve and clatter in the chase;
All flimsy were the pica-thugs,
And the quoins did bind the space.

“Beware the Platen-Press, my son!
The jaws that clench, the grippers snatch!
Beware the Tympan-sheet, and shun
The gloppish Inken-patch!”

He took his bodkin-knife in hand,
Long time the skerrick foe he sought—
So rested he by the type-high stand,
And stood in dwimmery thought.

And as in dwimmery thought he stood,
The Platen-Press, with eyes of brass,
Came clankering through the reglet-wood,
A-grolling as it passed!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The bodkin-knife went thwicker-thwack!
He left it dead, and with its flue,
He went debossing back.

“And hast thou slain the Platen-Press?
Come to my arms, my kernish boy!
O glorious day! Impress! Impress!”
He cheepled in his joy.

’Twas inky-dark, the leaden slugs
Did scryve and clatter in the chase;
All flimsy were the pica-thugs,
And the quoins did bind the space.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Cromlech Climb

’Twas flume-damp, and the scronky crags
Did gimble in the grey.
All flimsy were the vapour-flags,
And the mists did sloff and stray.

“Beware the Grimgripe, son, beware!”
The crag-fast man did cry,
“Its jaw, the piton’s ancient scar,
Its claws of scree nearby!”

He took his chalk-bag and his rope,
His chinkering carabine;
He climbed on grim and grippy hope,
And spurned the sheer incline.

He scaled the gliff, he sought the height,
The grundling wind did moan,
And saw it in the wuther-light,
The Grimgripe, etched in stone.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
He jammed his chock-stone tight,
It whicker-snapped the scar anew,
And filled the gape with might.

“And hast thou healed the piton scar?
Come to my arms, my sky-bright boy!
O gladdest day! Hurrah! Hurrah!”
He humphed aloud his joy.

’Twas flume-damp, and the scronky crags
Did gimble in the grey.
All flimsy were the vapour-flags,
And the mists did sloff and stray.

poem:
The Thrumble-Worp

’Twas heddling, and the spindly groves
Did scrythe and brangle in the shade;
All weftsome were the tangled coves,
And the loom-wraiths frayed.

“Beware the Thrumble-Worp, my son!
Its threads that bind, its sley-toothed jaw!
Its weftsome call, which few can shun,
And its ensnaring claw!”

He took his picker-blade in hand,
Long time the warpsome foe he sought—
So rested he by the selvage-land,
And stood in reedy thought.

And, as in threddled thought he stood,
The Thrumble-Worp, with eyes of spool,
Came birring through the warp-wood,
A knotting, brangling tool!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The picker-blade went zizzer-zane!
He left it shorn, its fibres flew,
And loosed the tangled skein.

“And hast thou slain the Thrumble-Worp?
Come to my arms, my woven boy!
O plaitful day! Heddle! Heddle-orp!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas heddling, and the spindly groves
Did scrythe and brangle in the shade;
All weftsome were the tangled coves,
And the loom-wraiths frayed.

poem:
The Snarksnatch's Stake

’Twas tindertime, the plinking sprockets
Did skirl and scrabble on the slag;
All clammivent were culvert-pockets,
And the grummock moaned its brag.

“Beware the Snarksnatch, son, my own!
Its hide of tin, its teeth that hone,
Beware the Gringrind bird, and shun
The scrimulous Mutter-piece!”

He took his tinnings-stake in hand,
His hammering-maul he hefted so;
And sought the foe in that bleak land,
Where Rumble-pumps all chugging grow.

And as in churlish thought he stood
Beneath a crank-shaft, grey with must,
The Snarksnatch, from the chitter-wood,
Came burbling forth in bolts of rust.

A-tapper-tap! And through and through,
The tinnings-stake went brissel-brack!
He left it sprent, and for a clue,
He lugged the whirring mainspring back.

“And hast thou slain the Snarksnatch? Come
To me, my grimsire boy, my ace!
Oh glorious day! Tin-tin! Tin-tum!”
He wheezed and clanked about the place.

’Twas tindertime, the plinking sprockets
Did skirl and scrabble on the slag;
All clammivent were culvert-pockets,
And the grummock moaned its brag.

poem:
The Inlaytor

’Twas lithic, and the chertish morns
Did score and scree the sky;
All sinter-sleek the carven thorns,
And the stone-doves flitter-fly.

“Beware the Inlaytor, my son!
The jaws that crack, the claws that chip!
Beware the Geode-bird, and shun
The malachitous grip!”

He took his glyptic blade in hand,
And sought the foe of carven stone,
He left the town for quarried land
And stood to think alone.

And as in flint-edged thought he stood,
The Inlaytor, with facet-fire,
Came scraling through the porphyry wood,
And geoded, in its ire!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The glyptic blade went sliver-smack!
He left it cleft, a polished blue,
And clatter-bounding, came he back.

“And hast thou slain the Inlaytor?
Come to my arms, my chiseled boy!
O Glimmer-bright! O Granolith!”
He gem-grinned in his glee.

’Twas lithic, and the chertish morns
Did score and scree the sky;
All sinter-sleek the carven thorns,
And the stone-doves flitter-fly.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Glumphing of the Glimmergloom

’Twas vesperblue, and the cristacrine snows
Did hushfall in the wood;
All mizzle-thin the umbralight goes,
And the rime-raw sapling stood.

“Beware the Glimmergloom, my son!
The breath of frost-blur white,
The chitter-claws that skitter-run,
The orb-ice in the night!”

He took his shard-axe, keen and cold,
And watched the indiglow;
A talecraft hero, grim and bold,
He sought the frigid foe.

He stood beneath a craggle-tree,
And heard, with dread profound,
A glumphing, slumpish misery
That shivered through the ground.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The shard-axe whicker-whacked!
It clove the gloom of spectral blue,
And left the horror cracked.

With Glimmergloom head, a frozen prize,
He strode back from the fray.
“My son!” the aged talecrafter cries,
“You’ve won the skymglow day!”

’Twas vesperblue, and the cristacrine snows
Did hushfall in the wood;
All mizzle-thin the umbralight goes,
And the rime-raw sapling stood.

poem:
The Snarlgrack

’Twas glumptious, and the slumber-ties
Did chudder in the sun;
All viscid in the humegloom,
The rail-wraiths were outrun.

"Beware the Snarlgrack, O my son!"
The grizzened sire he cried,
"Its chackling jaws, its breath of rust!
It waits the track beside."

So took his grapnel-hook so keen,
And left the village scene;
He clamber-scooted down the bank,
Where crossties smelled so keen.

And in the humegloom, stark and vast,
A shape of rivet-scale and bone!
With scrabbling claws it hurried past,
And gave a gantry-groan.

Thwack-whack! Thwack-whack! The hook bit deep!
The steel did screech and tear!
It left the monster in a heap,
And fouled the sickly air.

With rivet-scale held high and proud,
He slogged his homeward way;
The grizzened sire then cried aloud,
"Oh, splendrous, clanking day!"

’Twas glumptious, and the slumber-ties
Did chudder in the sun;
All viscid in the humegloom,
The rail-wraiths were outrun.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "balance spring collet". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Chronowhirl

’Twas timetwist, and the tocking gears
Did sclock and skirl within the case;
All whirlish were the planispheres,
And the second-space.

“Beware the Chronowhirl, my son!
The coil that strains, the claw that grips!
Beware the Breguet bird, and shun
Its horologic lips!”

He took his tweezing blade in hand;
Long time the escapement foe he sought—
So rested he by the mainspring stand,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in dial-deep thought he stood,
The Chronowhirl, with eyes of brass,
Came sproinging through the pallet-wood,
And ticked upon the grass.

One, two! One, two! The coil unbound!
The tweezing blade did cleave and set;
He broke the grip which time had wound,
And smashed the steel collet.

“And have you stopped the Chronowhirl?
Come to my arms, my timely boy!
O chronous day! Tempay! Tempore!”
He chimed out in his joy.

’Twas measured now, the tocking gears
Did click and whirr within the case;
All steady were the planispheres,
In the second-space.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pantograph arcing blue". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Gromulent Quell

’Twas glum, and the coggled ways
Did skirl in sooted haze;
All glimmergrime the maze
Of wires webbed the days.

“Beware the Vaporscritch, my son!
The charge that hums and zips,
The jangle-jawed, the one
That arcs from wire-tips.”

He took his null-rod in his hand,
Long had he sought this foe;
He trumbled through the land
Where charged conductors glow.

He stood beneath a copper-pole,
And waited, poised and still,
A thought within his soul
To bend it to his will.

It came! With flumphering sound,
The Vaporscritch did creep,
Its pantograph swung round,
A blue and crackling leap!

One-two! And through and through
The null-rod clattersnapped!
It quelled the arcing blue;
The circuit fizzed and trapped.

“And hast thou quelled the Vaporscritch?
Return, my gromulent son!”
He brought the silent twitch
Of pantograph, job done.

’Twas glum, and the coggled ways
Did skirl in sooted haze;
All glimmergrime the maze
Of wires webbed the days.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Stubble-Wight

’Twas gloam-shine, and the brissle-bare
Did skirr and chitter on the lea;
Beware the whirricle in air,
That fluthersome apostrophe.

“Beware the Stubble-Wight, my son!
The jaws that gibber, claws that clinch!
Its chitter-drone, once it’s begun,
Will bind you fast and never flinch.”

He took his glinting gleve in hand,
And paced the mirk-and-mizzle deep;
He searched the stubble-trodden land,
While all the gribbling crawlers sleep.

And as he stood, a-huff and high,
The whirricle, with rustling sound,
Did blot the dimming gloam-shine sky,
And peel the Stubble-Wight from ground.

It came on scritching, bristle-backed,
Its cry a keening, thin-edged whine!
The glinting gleve went thwack-a-thwack,
And clove its chittering, cheap design.

With chitin-chime held in his hand,
He strode back, far from fear’s employ.
“Oh gladsome morn! Throughout the land!”
His father chortled in his joy.

’Twas gloam-shine, and the brissle-bare
Did skirr and chitter on the lea;
Beware the whirricle in air,
That fluthersome apostrophe.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "pewter inlay ribbon". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Ribbonwroth

’Twas grimmock, and the glim-grey stones
Did scrimp and crinkle in the dray;
All mordent were the pewter-thrones,
And the grole vespels chimed away.

“Beware the Ribbonwroth, my son!
The spools that gleam, the strands that bind!
Beware the Flitter-flash, and shun
The glommering, umbrageous kind!”

He took his tin-wrought shears in hand,
Long time the crinkling foe he sought—
So rested he by the trillium-strand,
And stood a while in worble thought.

And as in worble thought he stood,
The Ribbonwroth, with eyes of inlay,
Came chitter-scrolling through the wood,
And burbled in its pewter-play!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The tin-wrought shears went clink-and-clack!
He left it snipped, its coils askew,
And with its head he came clombering back.

“And hast thou slain the Ribbonwroth?
Come to my arms, my gleesome boy!
O joy-bright day! Sing loo-la-lay!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas grimmock, and the glim-grey stones
Did scrimp and crinkle in the dray;
All mordent were the pewter-thrones,
And the grole vespels chimed away.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "linocut brayer chatter". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Brayerwock's Chatter

’Twas glummy, and the splacky slade
A frumming, chitter-noise had made.
The paper-shroves were vinkled deep,
Where coiled the gouge-ghouls in their sleep.

“Beware the Brayerwock, my son!
The jaws that blot, the eyes of tack!
Beware its skritching, once begun,
And shun its inky track!”

He took his gouge-glaive, sharp and long,
And sought his foe by lino-wood;
He hummed a carver's pressing-song,
And by the ink-slab stood.

And as in griptious thought he stayed,
The Brayerwock, with glummy roll,
Came pliffling through the carven glade,
And smeared its sticky soul.

One, two! One, two! The glaive did bite,
Its vinkled cuts went through and through!
He left it fixed, a block of night,
And pulled a print so true.

“And hast thou pressed the Brayerwock?
Come to my arms, my artist-lad!
O splackrous day! Upon the block!”
He chortled, press-ly glad.

’Twas glummy, and the splacky slade
A frumming, chitter-noise had made.
The paper-shroves were vinkled deep,
Where coiled the gouge-ghouls in their sleep.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "quarter‑sawn shimmer". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Glostervane

’Twas grackly, and the splinging grobes
Did chinter in the glade;
Beware the Glostervane, my son,
The woodgrain-shimmered blade!

Beware its grain, the glarring bite!
It comes with neither tread
Nor sound, but whiffles through the light
And fills the woods with dread.

He took his sketherskeen in hand,
Long had he kept it clean,
And went to find it in the land
Where it was feyly seen.

He stood beside a trillig tree,
His spirit taut, a line,
When wumphing through the wood came he,
A shifting, splintery sign.

Its gristed hide of oaken grain
Did ripple, warp, and scraid;
A hundred phantoms, slick as rain,
Within its shimmer played.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The sketherskeen went smack!
It flacker-flashed, and with a spew
The gristed grain did crack.

And in his hand, a shard so bright,
He brought that woody prize.
His father yarped in sheer delight,
With glemmer in his eyes.

’Twas grackly, and the splinging grobes
Did chinter in the glade;
Beware the Glostervane, my son,
The woodgrain-shimmered blade

poem:
The Chronowasp

’Twas horologe, and the tickle-tocks
Did skirr and stridulate the air;
All grummly were the balance-cocks,
And the moment-mites outgribe.

“Beware the Chronowasp, my son!
The drone that flits, the barbs that catch!
Beware the Cog-wight, and wisely run
The whickering Gearsnatch!”

He took his tweezle-tongs in hand;
Long time the chittering foe he sought—
So rested he by the fusee-stand,
And stood a while in thought.

And, as in whirlish thought he stood,
The Chronowasp, with eyes of rust,
Came skittering through the wheelwork wood,
And burbled as it bussed.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The tweezle-tongs went plicker-plack!
He plucked the screw, so blued of hue,
And bore its ruin back.

“And hast thou fixed the movement’s plight?
Come to my arms, my tink’rer boy!
O splendrous tick! O click so bright!”
He gibbled in his joy.

’Twas horologe, and the tickle-tocks
Did skirr and stridulate the air;
All grummly were the balance-cocks,
And the moment-mites outgribe.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Graphemoth

’Twas glimmer-tide, the waves were weech,
And flumphering far out from the beach,
All boats lay still in gloam-froth spray,
With a parrel bead upon a gaff-stay.

“Beware the Graphemoth, my lad!
Its chittering drives the sailors mad.
Beware its eye, the glinting sort,
That skerricks wood within the port.”

He took his flibbert-blade so keen,
The sharpest edge the docks had seen,
And sought the foe by mast and rope,
And clutched a salt-stained coil of hope.

And as he stood in thought so long,
He saw the bead was wholly wrong.
It pulsed and shone, a sickly shade,
No simple sphere a shipwright made.

It velloped then, a wingskin sprawl,
And clammered up beyond the pawl.
Its mandible began to clack,
His flibbert-blade went *thwack-a-thwack*!

He brought it back, the broken thing,
Still fastened to its parrel-string.
"Oh gladsome day!" his father cried,
"My son comes home with ocean's tide!"

’Twas glimmer-tide, the waves were weech,
And flumphering far out from the beach,
All boats lay still in gloam-froth spray,
With a parrel bead upon a gaff-stay.

poem:
The Crumbock's Rise

’Twas fermen, and the sloury grout
Did glyse and glim in the hearth-sheen;
All plimming were the levainblooms,
And mother-starters did outfroth.

"Beware the Crumbock, son, my own!
The jaws that glom, the crust that bites!
Beware the Sour-Stench, and shun
The proofing, puffous nights!"

His lamic blade he took in hand,
Long time the gluten-foe he sought—
So rested he by the proofter-gloom,
And stood awhile in thought.

And, as in doughsome thought he stood,
The Crumbock, with its yeast-warm soul,
Came levooning from the autolyse,
And made the baker whole.

One, two! The fold, the stretch, the tack!
The lamic blade went turn and pleat!
He tamed its rise, he bent it back,
And made the gluten sweet.

"And hast thou tamed the Crumbock wild?
Come to my arms, my bakeson bold!
O crispen day! Hurroo! Hurray!"
He shaped it in its mould.

’Twas fermen, and the sloury grout
Did glyse and glim in the hearth-sheen;
All plimming were the levainblooms,
And mother-starters did outfroth.

poem:
The Thrimbletack

’Twas scrolly, and the glimmer-weft
Did thrummer in the glade;
The lonely bobbins were bereft
Of patterns they had made.

“Beware the Thrimbletack, my son!
The jaws that skritch, the claws that fray!
Beware the Placket-bird, and shun
The Snarled Knot’s disarray!”

He took his spindleshank in hand,
His silver needle bright;
He sought it in that tattered land
By selvedge-scrub and light.

And, as in knotwork thought he stood,
The Thrimbletack, with whorl-eyed flame,
Came whimpling through the warp-wood,
And burble-blared its name!

One-two! One-two! With purpose true,
The spindleshank went tack-and-sew;
It stitched the rend, a seam of blue,
And laid the creature low.

“And hast thou mended it? Intact?
Come to my arms, my stitcher-son!
O puckerous day! Upon this fact,
A greater peace is won!”

’Twas scrolly, and the glimmer-weft
Did thrummer in the glade;
The lonely bobbins were bereft
Of patterns they had made.

poem:
The Glimmergast

’Twas umbral, and the vaporsleek
Did scrythe within the haze;
The filigrees did chitter-spark
In chrono-gladed maze.

“Beware the Glimmergast, my son!
The digits that enthrall,
Beware its hum, and shun, oh shun,
Its gimble-eyed call!”

He took his volt-glaive in his hand,
Long time the foe he sought.
He rested by a cathode-strand,
And stood a while in thought.

And as in glumphish thought he stood,
The Glimmergast, with eyes of flame,
Came whifflingly through the wire-wood,
And flickered as it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The volt-glaive went zizzer-zack!
It fell, its numen-bright hue
Did fade to sullen black.

“And hast thou slain the Glimmergast?
Come to my arms, my luminous boy!
Oh, happy day! Hurrah! At last!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas umbral, and the vaporsleek
Did scrythe within the haze;
The filigrees did chitter-spark
In chrono-gladed maze.

poem:
The Grumplegloat

’Twas slummery, and the gloam-gorse
Did skirl upon the brae;
All chortle-spined the sludge-mools crept,
And frumbled in the fey.

“Beware the Grumplegloat, my son!
The jaws that blunder-bite,
The claws that latch, the gloom it spun,
The murk-wraith of the night!”

He took his glave-hook, keen and fast,
And sought the morkish foe;
Long by the gimmer-tree he passed,
And waited, breathing low.

And as in quumish thought he stood,
The Grumplegloat, with eyes of glist,
Came whiffle-snorting through the wood,
And burbled in the mist.

With glave-hook bright, a swivelling arc,
The fishtail feint he made;
Then gouged its hide, so poggle-dark,
And swept the flensing blade!

He hefted up its snaggle-head,
Still dripping glope and slack,
And tromple-strode, his foeman dead,
Upon the journey back.

“Thou’st slain the Grumplegloat indeed!
Lay down its head, my boy!
O fluminous day! A victor’s deed!”
He warbled in his joy.

’Twas slummery, and the gloam-gorse
Did skirl upon the brae;
All chortle-spined the sludge-mools crept,
And frumbled in the fey.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "letter kept in a cedar box". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Flarthgloom's Keep

’Twas poldertime, the mimsy dells
Did grool and burble in the wood;
All clum the script, and in its cells
The cedar coffer stood.

“Beware the Flarthgloom, son, beware!”
The father spake with chorkled breath,
“The claws that clink, the gloomful stare!
Its whirring brings a frithful death.”

He took his glim-key, lithe and long,
And sought the scent of cedar-stain;
He hummed a blattish, tuneless song
And passed the weeping, mizzle-rain.

He found it by the carven chest,
The Flarthgloom, vast and vumidly;
Its oaken eyes held no behest,
Its form was pure tristfully.

With steady hand and purpose true,
The glim-key slid within the crack;
The tumlock gave a silvern grue,
And turned the warding latchward back.

The Flarthgloom gave a piteous moan
And seemed to unfray in the air;
It shrivelled from its wooden throne,
And left but scenting silence there.

“And hast thou claimed the secret script?
Come to my arms, my trepid boy!
Oh, muted day! The truth unzipped!”
He wept with grim and mournful joy.

’Twas poldertime, the mimsy dells
Did grool and burble in the wood;
All clear the script, and from its cells
The cedar coffer stood.

poem:
The Klackerklap

’Twas zimmering, and the volt-ways dim
Did brabble on the wire,
While audions hummed a voltic hymn
To sparks of chitter-fire.

“Beware the Klackerklap, my son!
The jaws that jib, the sparks that bite!
Beware the Sig-tree, and shun
The grangling code of night!”

He took his grounding-rod in hand,
Long time the voltic foe he sought,
Then by the Sig-tree took his stand
And waited, deep in thought.

And, as in brangled thought he stood,
The Klackerklap, with coils agleam,
Came clattering from the ether-wood,
A jibber-clacking stream!

Dit-dah! Dit-dah! The rod so fast
Went clicking, sharp and true!
He broke the code, its form uncast,
And ran its circuit through.

“And hast thou stilled the Klackerklap?
Come to my arms, my clever son!
The line is clear without a gap,
Your ditting task is done!”

’Twas zimmering, and the volt-ways dim
Did brabble on the wire,
While audions hummed a voltic hymn
To sparks of chitter-fire.

poem:
The Fiddle-Rosined Fiend

’Twas glimmerous, and the skritching dust
Did spin and fritz in amber light;
The resin-scraves were dry and crust,
And made a sound both thin and high.

“Beware the Gripteryx, my son!
The drone that grates, the claws that grip!
Beware the Strum-bird, and go shun
The whifflesnort from its chapped lip!”

He took his bow-blade sharp in hand,
And searched the woods of skirling pine;
He crossed the drone-struck, dusty land,
To still its harsh and grating whine.

And as in grummish thought he stood,
The Gripteryx, with strings of hair,
Came scraling through the resin-wood,
And chitter-strummed upon the air!

Scritch-scrunch! Scritch-scrunch! It sawed and drew,
The amber beast, with dusty breath;
The bow-blade scritched and scracced it through,
And left it strummified in death.

“And art thou come, the victor-kin?
Come to my arms, my plucky boy!
Thou’st stilled that shrill and strident din!
Oh soundous day! A thrumming joy!”

’Twas glimmerous, and the skritching dust
Did spin and fritz in amber light;
The resin-scraves were dry and crust,
And made a sound both thin and high.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Shave-Hog’s Whick

’Twas grilight, and the whirrum motes
Did gyre and glintle in the air;
All grylic were the plane-iron totes,
And the timber in despair.

“Beware the Shave-Hog, son, my own!
The blade that bites, the edge that brags!
Its scranky claws, its grylic groan,
It leaves but splinter-spalls and snags.”

He took his iron, stark and flat,
And sought the gronking water-stone;
He ground a smile where corners sat,
And made its gleaming camber known.

And, as in uffish thought he stood
Plane-poised above the mellowwood,
The Shave-Hog came! It chidder-chawed,
A track of tear and gash-abhorred.

One! Two! And through and through
The cambered edge went shicker-shack!
It peeled a ribband, flimmery new,
And left no grylic on its track.

“And hast thou slain the Shave-Hog? Go!
Come to my arms, my gleesome boy!
O frabjous cut! Huzzah! Bravo!”
He chortled in his workshop joy.

’Twas grilight, and the whirrum motes
Did gyre and glintle in the air;
All gleesome were the plane-iron totes,
And the timber in repair.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "orin bell hum". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Orin-Bell Hum

’Twas in the scronky, krangled drells,
The mosses grew so glum,
Beware the Bell, whose droning spells
Create the Orin-Hum.

“Beware the sound, my son, my son!
The air that glimes and mazes,
The wits that fray when it has spun
Its mind-unnerving phrases.”

He took his null-blade in his hand,
Long time the hum he sought;
He left the still and silent land,
And stood in flumfish thought.

It came then, skirling from the drell,
A ghast-thing, bronze and vast;
The air began to thrum and swell,
A shadow that it cast.

One, two! And with a silent bite
The null-blade chitter-chanked!
It cleft the Bell, and quenched its light.
The glade was stilled and blanked.

“And is the Orin-Bell un-made?
Come smiling to my knee!
You quelled its hum with your null-blade,
How gruffled I now be!”

’Twas in the scronky, krangled drells,
The air is light and calm;
No longer sound the droning spells,
Nor Orin-Bell’s deep hum.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Fathomsleep

’Twas bracksish, and the scurl-tides ran,
My father grumphed, his voice a drone,
“Beware the Fathomsleep, my man,
Whose quenching brine hiss chills the bone.”

He took his glaive-gleam, long in hand,
And sought the vesperdeep so grey;
He left the warm and worral sand
To hunt the horror far away.

He stood beside the craggle-spires,
Then out it came with gorgle-spume,
Its eyes like two balefulest fires,
And fluthering from the ocean’s gloom.

One-two! One-two! And through and through
The hiss-huffed scald-spray steamed the air;
His keenest blade went snicker-snew!
He leapt to foil its lashing snare.

The monster fell, its fury spent,
A quenching brine hiss filled the shore;
Its fiery throat was gashed and rent,
It would not fluther any more.

“And hast thou slain the Fathomsleep?
Come to my arms, my glaffish boy!
Oh frabjous day! The crags can keep!”
He chortled in his ulfing joy.

’Twas bracksish, and the scurl-tides ran,
My father grumphed, his voice a drone,
“Beware the Fathomsleep, my man,
Whose quenching brine hiss chills the bone.”

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Gnarlenbloom

’Twas grumblous, and the wimpled wealds
Did flimmer in the mire;
Beware the Gnarlenbloom, my child,
Its knot-of-badger fire!

He took his snicker-steel in hand
And strode the scracious lea,
To seek the vultrous Gnarlenbloom
And set the thicket free.

And as by slibbery fens he crept,
He saw a fulgent light—
The Gnarlenbloom! It pulsed and wept
All milk-and-moonstone white.

Its tendrils lashed with grabbulous might,
A-whickering with glee;
They snarled his legs in clampen-tight,
To pull him ’neath the lea.

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The snicker-steel did flay!
It severed clean the croodled root,
And lopped the bloom away.

“And hast thou slain the Gnarlenbloom?
Come home, my gleemish son!
Let joyous banners quell the gloom,
The dolorous task is done!”

’Twas grumblous, and the wimpled wealds
Did flimmer in the mire;
All safe, the Gnarlenbloom, my child,
Extinct its badger-fire.

poem:
The Gracklesnatch

’Twas gloming, and the spindly firs
Did thrumper in the fen;
All glumptious were the quill-burrs,
And the smuming glen.

“Beware the Gracklesnatch, my child!
The jaws that scrunch, the breath so raw,
That stridulous shriek, so shrill and wild,
Beware the nib-tine claw!”

He took his glint-steel blade in hand,
Long time the baneful foe he sought—
Then left behind the grumbling land
For glades of chittered thought.

And, as in glade-gloom deep he stood,
Its eyes a micro-mesh of fright,
The Gracklesnatch, from out the wood,
Came scritchling through the light.

One, two! And through and skewer-through!
The glint-steel blade went Snip and Clash!
He split the spifflic head in two
And quelled its baleful flash.

And has thou quelled the Gracklesnatch?
Come to my arms, my peerless boy!
O, glorious day! Unlatch the latch!
Klang-klink! Express thy joy!

’Twas gloming, and the spindly firs
Did thrumper in the fen;
All glumptious were the quill-burrs,
And the smuming glen.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "krenovian plane throat". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Gullet-Glider's Groan

’Twas skirling, and the skirty coves
Did gride and grinch the whittle-wough;
The spalt-scaled toves were in the groves,
And moaning, made the marrow bow.

“Beware the Gullet-Glider, son!
The jaws that plane, the teeth that shrave!
Beware the Skritch-bird, and yet shun
The Krenovian’s flensing, splintered knave!”

He took his glimmerglaive in hand,
Long time the scrofulous foe he sought—
He strode across the shivered land
And paused in chuntered, anxious thought.

And as in chuntered thought he stood,
The Gullet-Glider, with eyes of knot,
Came whiffling through the grummlewood,
Its cedar-scent all churring hot!

One flitch! Two flitch! And down it came,
The glimmerglaive went thack-and-thwack!
He left it kerned, a splintered frame,
And took its plane-throat, slung on back.

“And hast thou felled the throat so wide?”
The old man beamed. “My lathing-boy!
Oh glormious day! Cast fear aside!”
He chortled in his whittling joy.

’Twas skirling, and the skirty coves
Did gride and grinch the whittle-wough;
The spalt-scaled toves were in the groves,
And moaning, made the marrow bow.

Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. poem:
The Pluvial Plunk

’Twas droplic, and the grumbling clouds
Did chyme and clattle in the grey;
All shivvering were the windly shrouds,
And the mists came fuming all the day.

“Beware the Pluvial Plunk, my child!
The drums that drumble, the drops that bite!
Beware the din-beast, piskitter-wild,
And shun the roracket of the night!”

He took his pillomuff in hand;
Long time the tin-toned foe he sought.
So rested he by the window-stand,
And stood awhile in woeful-dole thought.

And as in gummished thought he stood,
The Pluvial Plunk, with eyes of rain,
Came pitter-pattering through the wood,
And tintangled on the pane!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The pillomuff blockt the pelting sound!
It left the roof, of drips askew,
And he fell asleep, secure and sound.

“And hast thou quelled the Pluvial Plunk?
Come to my arms, my peaceful boy!
Oh, silent day! Trankwillow! Sunk!”
He napped in his triumphish joy.

’Twas droplic, and the grumbling clouds
Did chyme and clattle in the grey;
All shivvering were the windly shrouds,
And the mists came fuming all the day.

poem:
The Gyokurōgast

’Twas teasteep, and the vumid wisps
Did flurl and gyre within the clay;
All mimsy were the grassy lisps,
Upon that tannic day.

“Beware the Gyokurōgast, my son!
The jaws that burn, the claws that steep!
Beware the Kusa-bird, and shun
The frumious Astringeep!”

He took his kyusu pot in hand;
Long time the bitter foe he sought—
And roamed the chawan-patterned land,
And stood awhile in chot.

And as in chotish thought he stood,
The Gyokurōgast, with eyes of steam,
Came trillicking through the tenmoku wood,
And burbled with a hissing gleam.

One, two! One, two! And drip and drip!
The kyusu spout went plink-a-plack!
He left it steeped, and with a sip,
He brought the umame back.

“And hast thou brewed the Gyokurōgast?
Come to my cup, my beamish boy!
Now from its bitter bane thou’rt passed!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas teasteep, and the vumid wisps
Did flurl and gyre within the clay;
All mimsy were the grassy lisps,
Upon that tannic day.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "split‑grade enlarger burn". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Spildergrox

’Twas brilgent, and the vapoursleeth
Did crope and chumble in the fume;
All chem-stenched were the vats beneathe,
And the fuming phote-spumes gloom.

“Beware the Spildergrox, my son!
The lens that glares, the rays that char!
Beware the Dodgeling, and shun
The glumptious Gradial-bar!”

He took his luming blade in hand;
Long time the photic foe he sought—
So rested he by the Safelight tree,
And stood awhile in thought.

And as in gradial thought he stood,
The Spildergrox, with eye of flare,
Came skeltching through the hypo-wood,
And sizzled on the air!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The luming blade went sivver-sift!
He left it scathed, a form bereft,
And took its focul-core as gift.

“And hast thou slain the Spildergrox?
Come to my arms, my gleamful boy!
Oh gladsome print! Hooray! Hooray!”
He chartled in his joy.

’Twas brilgent, and the vapoursleeth
Did crope and chumble in the fume;
All chem-stenched were the vats beneathe,
And the fuming phote-spumes gloom.

prompt: Write a poem in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Your prompt is "kiridashi scribe line". Your poem will be graded for adherence to these criteria: title; quatrains; meter; rhyme; ring (ending echoes the beginning); warning; preparation; encounter; decisive act; return; coinages; coinage spread; creature naming; onomatopoeia; alliteration; arc order; no verbatim copying; canonical budget (limit use of distinctive words from the original poem); syllable tightness; rhyme variety; repetition guard; coinage variety; topic adherence; subtext. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Scriberwock’s Mark

’Twas glommering, and the flenchy gworms
Did quimper in the slade;
All scrabrous were the greeblestones,
And the far-off spregs outgrade.

“Beware the Scriberwock, my son!
The edge that thinks, the point that schemes!
Beware the Gruffsnout bird, and shun
The grupt and chundering streams.”

He took his chirpal steel in hand,
And sought the Murkscrave deep;
He ranged across the griptive land
While all the world did sleep.

And, as in gravis thought he stood,
The Scriberwock, with point of blight,
Came lolloping through the mirksome wood,
And skreaked with cold delight!

A flash of steel, a keen-drawn prayer,
The chirpal point did score!
It scribed a line upon the air,
And the beast was beast no more.

“And hast thou marked the Scriberwock?
Come to my arms, my gleeful boy!
O gladsome day! Hooray! Hooray!”
He chortled in his joy.

’Twas glommering, and the flenchy gworms
Did quimper in the slade;
All scrabrous were the greeblestones,
And the far-off spregs outgrade.
